review_title: "Empower others and promote well-being as a Peer Health Educator"
job_title: Peer Health Educator in Newark, DE
pros: There are several potential pros for a job as a peer health educator at UD (University of Delaware), including: Opportunity to help others: As a peer health educator, you would have the chance to help fellow students improve their health and well-being. This can be very rewarding and satisfying, as you can directly see the impact of your work on others. Build valuable skills: This job can help you build important skills such as public speaking, communication, leadership, and project management. You would also gain knowledge about health topics that can be applied to your personal life and future career. Flexible schedule: Many peer health education programs offer flexible scheduling, allowing you to balance work with classes, other jobs, or extracurricular activities. Work with a supportive team: Peer health educators often work in a team of other students who share similar interests and goals. This can create a sense of community and support, as well as provide opportunities for networking and socializing. Gain valuable experience for future careers: This job can be a great way to gain experience that is relevant to many future careers in health, wellness, education, counseling, and more. It can also be a valuable addition to your resume and show potential employers that you are passionate about helping others. Overall, being a peer health educator can be a fulfilling and worthwhile job, with potential benefits for both personal and professional growth.
cons: While working as a peer health educator at UD can be a rewarding and fulfilling experience, there are some potential cons to consider: Limited hours and pay: Peer health educators are often employed on a part-time basis, with limited hours and lower pay than some other jobs on campus. Emotional demands: Peer health educators may have to deal with emotionally challenging situations, such as supporting students dealing with mental health issues, sexual assault, or substance abuse. This can be difficult and stressful, especially for those who are new to the role. Training requirements: Peer health educators typically have to complete extensive training, which can be time-consuming and demanding. This can be a barrier for those who are not able to commit to the required training schedule. Limited career growth: While the experience gained as a peer health educator can be valuable, there may be limited career growth opportunities in this field. Working with diverse populations: Peer health educators may need to work with students from different backgrounds and with diverse needs, which can be challenging and require a high level of cultural competency. It's important to weigh these potential cons against the benefits of the job and your personal goals and priorities before deciding whether to pursue a position as a peer health educator at UD or elsewhere.

review_title: Lots of work, low  pay, little recognition, no opportunity
pros: The benefits package is very nice. Good medical/sick days/paid vacation. And the campus is very beautiful at certain times of the year. the town is nice too.
cons: I've worked here for eight years. In all that time, my largest raise amounted to 1.5%. If I was the only wage earner in my household, I could not afford to live. I'd like to find a better position on campus but there are no opportunities. I have two advanced degrees so I'm not lacking in qualifications. When I attempted to show initiative and began work on a project to streamline aspects of my department's workflow, with my supervisor's knowledge and approval, I was eventually reprimanded by my supervisor during my annual performance review as a "loose cannon." My current supervisor, reflecting the attitude of her supervisor, makes no plans and communicates what plans there are poorly if at all. All in all, work is stressful, frustrating, and ultimately futile.

pros: Flexible schedule, generous 403(B) contribution.

pros: There are many lifers at UD. UD offers state benefit plans with free college education for immediate family members, excellent health, dental, vision, short/long term disability, 11% 401K match. The work/life balance is also built into the culture with 22 vacation days a year and 18 sick days a year, which can be used for dependent care. The University is also closed between Christmas and New Year's, which doesn't count toward your vacation. There are very lenient work-from-home options in my department.
cons: We are between presidents right now, and there is a lot unknown about Dr. Assanis, who starts in June and has never been a college president. The very low pay (exactly half of what I was paid in the commercial sector) really takes an adjustment. As with all jobs, it usually comes down to your immediate manager, and I don't see much development for poor managers. My entire team is looking for work, and we've already lost a few really good people.

review_title: Terrible for me, but probably not indicative of true experience
pros:
Good benefits
Good on boarding experience
Tuition reinbursment
Feels like a real community & lots of very intelligent people
Perks of working at a large university in a small city
cons:
Pay low compared to similar private sector jobs
A lot of after-hours & weekend work expected for no extra pay
Long interview/hiring process with multiple team and peer interviews. Understandable, but it can be excessive for the candidate with 5-6 people at once.
Advanced degrees required!
Ivory Tower mentality at times

My experience at UDel was not good. But I admit that this was mainly due to my manager and not the University overall. The position was not what it was purported to be, and it led to dissatisfaction on both parts a very short tenure there as a result. I found out later I was not the candidate the manager wanted to hire, and thus this relationship was doomed from the start.

pros: Working in higher education is really fulfilling when you get to see students find better opportunities to succeed. Being around academics and educators are a better alternative than working with trained monkeys at a large financial institution. And you can't beat having free access to the gym and swimming pool. Also had great mentors as a first-time employee.
cons:
Corporate benefactors like JPMorgan, Gore, and DuPont, influence many major decisions at the top-level. Of course you can't argue with someone who's giving you free money, but at least try to find better alternatives.
As with every organization it's always tough to break free from the bureaucratic rigidness of how things must get done. It can be a limitation to creative ideas but you'll just have to find the right people who can carry on your idea.

review_title: Being a Teaching Assistant for the Computer Science department  is fun but time consuming
pros: The pay is pretty good for an undergraduate position, and it's fun helping the students. Office hours are a good time to catch up on work as students usually only visit when they have a major project or exam coming up.
cons:
Depending on who you TA for you may get anywhere from  very little instruction on your duties  to a professor micromanaging how you grade or run lab. Make sure to actively contact the professor you are TAing for even if they are not reaching out to you. 

Many times, the amount of work required by the job varies widely by the week. Pay attention to when the student's due dates are as that will help give you a rough idea of how much time you will have to spend grading. If they are struggling with an assignment, it will make it harder and more time consuming to grade.

review_title: The University of Delaware is the premier education institution in research in the mid-Atlantic region
pros: The location of UD is a short drive from most of the major cities in the area including Wilmington, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington D.C. and even NYC. It has a committed dedication to growth with the new Star Campus and is know for it's support of students financially and academically.
cons: The UD has a ways to go in creating an inclusive environment that is welcoming to groups of diverse backgrounds, whether it be race, ethnicity, sexual orientation or disability, but strives are occurring. Also, as a research institution there must be much much more emphasis on supporting graduate students who a both students and faculty as well as full-time professionals that rewards the work they do in terms of research, teaching and service

review_title: Great place to work, but somewhat limited upside potential if not tenure track faculty
pros: Benefits, work environment, and resources were all excellent.  Facilities and equipment were also outstanding, and overall cultural and local environment were very good.
cons: Limited upside potential for advancement in field.  Salaries were lower than equivalent business and government positions in most cases.  Rigidity of large organization in policies and political correctness was frustrating.

job_title: Research Associate II in Newark, DE
pros: This is a good institution for those in research who like a small town feel, but good research. The research community is diverse, the benefits are amazing. The leadership and community feel really depends on the department and supervisor you have. Overall, the living expenses in the surrounding communities are less, yet the benefit programs here are really good.
cons: They don't necessarily provide a whole lot of training depending on the department you enter. Again, the office culture depends on the department you go to. I've heard and seen really good office culture, and really bad office culture. I suggest you really talk to those in the department you are entering into first. If you are in the research community hoping for a lot of contact and communication across disciplines, don't have high hopes.

review_title: University of Delaware, a university attempting to answer the big questions in higher education.
pros:
Great benefits
Beautiful workplace
Sincere commitment to professional development
It is a university that is really trying to address the issues that is facing higher ed. There is a lot of funding in the student affairs and student services areas.  it is a large institution and most people put students first.
cons: The pace and the workload is very high in student affairs. there is very little concern about work life balance and we are plagued by the new RBB responsibility based budgeting, and virtually no ability to give raises to people who are doing better work than others in their department.  People stay in their jobs for a long time, so not a lot of upward movement for entry levels.

pros: There are some brilliant people, many of whom are also decent to work with.  The hours tend to be flexible if you are in a lab or office.
cons: Lots of politics, substance is less important than marketing.  The administration/management is very disconnected from the real needs of both employees and students.  It is hard to get a full time position.  Everything is about inflating the school's status, not improving the actual quality.

review_title: Good opportunity - Glad I worked there
pros:
department was well funded
department advocated for most professionals
work was founded in theory and research
dedicated to assessment and strong work ethic

cons:
No one leaves so not many opportunities for growth
You're expected to "pay your dues" and work too many hours

Curse of the competent - many people skate by doing very little and those who have proven to be strong employees get more and more responsibility with little to no compensation

review_title: IT Assistant College of Arts & Sciences.
pros: Great management, worked with some great people, and enjoyed my experience helping professors, staff, and students across different campuses up and down the state.
cons: Only con here was the parking situation.  I had to leave the job because I was forced to cut my hours down to my school schedule, and would have ended up losing money because of how ridiculous parking is priced.  I strongly recommend offering free/ discounted to employees of the school.

pros: Medium sized university. This is nice because you can be familiar with everyone in the department fairly easily. It's also situated close to other business and culture centers.
cons: Newark as a town does not have too much going on, which could be good for you depending on what you're in to. I am a graduate student, so my adviser is my boss. This is the biggest factor in whether you will enjoy your time in grad school, so get to know him/her before you get to school.

review_title: Clique - Bureaucratic - Executives & Professors have no real-world experience
pros: Enjoying working and engaging with students.
cons: It is 100% clear that the school cares about money more than they do their students. Multiple layers of bureaucracy. Hiring is 100% geared toward internal. Many who do nothing or incompetent. Politics of central marketing and individual school marketing. At the school level, you have no say. Not the real world. Most have never worked in the real-world, including the professors. HR is the worst.

pros:

- Professors are knowledgeable and friendly

cons:

If you live IN Newark, the students can be a bit of a hassle (college town). Living outside of Newark can put you in the middle of suburban hell...

review_title: Laboratory Technician at University of Delaware
job_title: Limited Term Researcher (College of Agriculture and Natural Resources) in Newark, DE
pros: Benefits are excellent, and  for the most part  there is a good degree of flexibility in work hours.  The community  is helpful in  general (although somewhat compartmentalized by the type of research being conducted).
cons: Because the university (or at least the Ag department) has shifted away from hiring permanent full-time technical staff, many of the science-based technical positions are contingent on grant funding.  This makes long-term job stability questionable.   It can also limit avenues for career advancement.

pros: Although there was a recent increase in the cost of benefits, overall the university provides great benefits between health, education, and free use of the gym. The overall climate of the university is a friendly one, with many opportunities to take on responsibilities outside of your department and to connect with others.
cons: This could vary on department, but at times it seems there is very little transparency from the administration. One area of UD I am also not impressed with is how they handle diversity, specifically with various races. A lot more can be done from the administration to develop a more inclusive community for non-white students.

pros:
Engaged and motivated students
First-rate colleagues
Gorgeous campus
Friendly and energetic vibe
People respect you and you're treated fairly
Mentally stimulating
Who could ask for anything more?
cons:
Crowded small town
Difficult parking
Pay to park and the garages have problems like being so full you can't get in or suddenly making you pay in cash when you want to leave.
As usual adjunct faculty make very little (low salary)
Work life balance can be an issue because grading, planning, and prepping is done at home. But hey that's teaching. You don't get into the business for the money or to have a life.
Also, you need to know someone to get a job as an adjunct here.

job_title: English Language Institute Homestay in Newark, DE
pros:
Opportunity to meet and interact with students of different cultures
Opportunity to share your family with a student who is far from home.
Opportunity to demonstrate to students of other countries American life.
Opportunity to earn extra income
cons:
It is like having company, all the time, who never, ever leave.  Can be stressful.
Have to keep home company clean all the time, and plan extra activities that you normally would not do.
It is an adjustment to have someone with different habits, not related, living in the home.

review_title: UD is OK, Depts make or break it
pros: UD as a whole is fine - generous benefits and perks.  Some departments are great because of great managers.
cons: Most managers are clueless - the Peter Principal is in full effect and HR avoids fixing things.  The amount of red tape is ridiculous, and things often move at a snails pace on a good day.

review_title: A good place to get a PhD.
pros: Career service center is helpful. They have a good study-abroad program. Graduate students can also benefit from that. individual satisfaction depends on your advisor. Chemical engineering is definitely the best program in the university. Location is wonderful. There is a good Higher Education Teaching program if you would like to teach in a liberty/art college in the future.
cons: University is not so supportive for graduate students, especially for housing and parking. The parking becomes horrible beginning this year.

review_title: Ice arena is a very uninviting place to work
pros:
good facility
Good ice at arena to skate on
College hockey games
Always have work to do
Free shirts and jackets for some positions
cons:
full time staff are very sarcastic and not straight forward with you
All training is poorly conducted and almost self taught
Supervisors goof off while on the job
Office employees are mean and rude to part-time college staff

pros: Benefits, including retirement contribution, tuition for dependents and time off are generous.  Healthcare benefit is still good, despite recent increases in healthcare costs to employees,  Beautiful campus.
cons: Heavy workload, negative atmosphere in terms of politics and favoritism, employees are not valued or respected.  This can vary depending on the department and within organizational units.

review_title: They should pay bio grad students more
pros: For the most part it is a professional environment. Smart faculty, and amicable staff. I would not say friendly though. Excellent education, and they actually pay master's students.
cons:
I liked working as a research assistant at UD, however it was hard live on what we were paid. Especially since they require that we pay student fees an such.

Also, faculty some faculty seem clueless as to how to treat alleged "minorities". It's best to chalk it up as inexperience with diverse populations (another thing UD needs to work on, not necessarily import a bunch of international people and leave them in their own groups)...

pros: Wonderful set of people who are genuinely caring and willing to support you to the next step in life. I've met several individuals who are closer to me than family here.
cons: Getting promoted is ridiculously hard. You have to apply for years until something comes through.  Most cases, you have to meet criteria that's not in the job description. Knowing someone in the department you're applying to doesn't guarantee you anything anymore.

review_title: No longer values employees... only values the dollar!
pros: The university offers a great benefits package, 4 weeks paid vacation and 2 weeks sick leave.
cons: Since Harker has become president of the University there has been an overall change in the environment. Money is now the bottom line, it is no longer about providing a great education, maintaining quality staff or providing service to the State (all of which I though were great characteristics when I began working here 7 years ago). It's sad that the vision of the institution has changed!!

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Newark, DE
pros:
-As a grad student, you get paid to continue your education
-Fair amount of academic freedom, as a student
-Pretty much make your own hours
cons:
-Newark is a very small town.
-Culture is difficult to figure out. Professor politics abound. 
-You will have time for one hobby in addition to coursework, research, and teaching responsibilities
-In conjunction with the above, your work-life balance is fairly non-existent
-Not much say in the courses you actually teach

pros: For a small university, the concentration of talented, proficient talent doing engineering research in a relatively stress free setting was astounding.
cons: Graduate students rights were virtually non-existent  and some of the university policies are pretty archaic, this University has a backwards code of ethics that are years behind anything I've ever seen. The new models of running each department of universities like business have there share of growing pains.

pros: Nice college town, decent financial support (by graduate school standards), reasonable teaching demands, relatively stress-free.  The University of Delaware had some great fellow graduate students in my cohort.
cons: Office politics could get nasty.  There were a couple bad eggs in the faculty (I won't name names).    The undergraduate students were not exactly Ivy League caliber, and some were just apathetic and/or rude.

pros: Nothing, other than you get to live in the most unfriendly place on earth...literally there are prisons that are more friendly.
cons: They steel your money (you will only receive about 1/2 of what they say, and they will claim some BS reason for which you can't get the rest), they will put up every road block for you to get paid at all, and then they will pay you through the wrong mechanism so that you can't get the tax exemptions you should.

review_title: Really nice university although the Lewes campus is small.
pros: I spent my time at the Lewes campus and it was a bit limiting after several years of graduate study. The community is very small on this campus, but they do have their own research vessels which makes sampling the bay water easy. The University itself is fair.
cons: For graduate students the benefits are almost non-existent, but that is to be expected for students. The only place to live on-campus is Daiber student housing and it's not conducive to people of all ages, mostly college age kids.

review_title: Great salary and benefits but a very different work culture.
pros: A variety of options to move laterally into up to certain levels. Salary is actually competitive and the benefits are awesome.
cons: It is easy to get pigeon-holed or cap off at the professional level. After working a few years there are very few opportunities to advance. Many choose to leave in order to move up.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Newark, DE
pros: A great place to do research and gain experience in various kinds of labs. Room for growth and movement, granted that you stick with the research project and show your interest in doing so.
cons:
Considerably low pay for job that requires so much dedication
Working from home, or taking tasks home to keep working on them is almost never allowed, seeing that data must remain in the lab

pros: At the University of Delaware you will find professors who are at or near the tops of their fields with many connections to government and private sector career opportunities.  Research is done on the cutting edge of new and exciting technologies and new money and recognition is continuously pouring into the college of engineering.
cons: Large disconnect between upper management (department/college chairs/deans) and lower professors and students at times with respect to department/college plans.

pros: There are great benefits and Newark is a nice area, however, it's difficult to enjoy the perks of living in the area during the academic year.
cons: Unreasonable expectations, ridiculous taxes on classes that employees can take "for free," that eat up your entire paycheck, and etc.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Newark, DE
pros: Vacation days and Sick days are great. Everybody in my department work well together and it's a family away from home. I absolutely love my job and co-workers. The benefits are great, you can get a degree for free while working here. My daughters can go to school here when they are older and your spouse can as well. You can't beat that.
cons: You have to pay for parking which is ridiculous. Just like the old saying the early bird gets the worm. Well the early employee gets a parking spot.

job_title: Senior Lead Technician in Newark, DE
pros: The supervisors are understanding of the role of the student worker within the University. They will go out of their way to aid in your personal and professional advancement inside and outside of the office.
cons: Miscellaneous wage workers are restricted to working 28 hours a week. There is no work when school is not in session.

pros: Professional development offerings are abundant, the work environment is generally very good, and benefits are excellent.
cons: Positions are very dependent upon direct supervisor... be sure to seek information regarding salary support (e.g., hard v. soft money), classification status, and opportunities for career growth.

pros: A great community to be a part of.  A lot of advancement for the University in the years to come with new buildings and programs
cons: As a student, if you get a position with the wrong faculty member or in the wrong area of Residence Life you can be very dissatisfied.  Do yous research before deciding to work somewhere.

pros: Good perks like education benefits for yourself, spouse and dependents and very high 401K contributions. Beautiful campus.
cons: Each college/department is run independently so very little collaboration. Professional teams are small, not diverse and use many outdated processes and procedures. Many programs and centers are faculty-led and they not held accountable for poor management. No career advancement unless you're lucky enough to have your position is reclassified. Compensation & job titles are not consistent throughout organization and not comparable to industry.

pros: I was able to interact with a lot of students and faculty.  I often helped them get on track to reach their fitness goals or answered any basic questions they had for me.
cons: We were not asked to do any specific tasks besides clean off the equipment while there were countless other duties that could have been completed.

job_title: Senior Research Analyst in Newark, DE
pros: The University of Delaware is one of the best places to work in the country. The administration values their workers and show the utmost respect for students and staff.
cons: While there are few downsides to working at the University of Delaware, I would have to say that one notable con would be the lacking of adequate parking for the staff.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Newark, DE
pros:
Positive interactions with my department (Earth Sciences). The faculty, staff, and students are very kind and helpful.

The University has excellent facilities (labs, library, gym).

Stipend covers the cost of living in Newark, DE.

Grad student health insurance is affordable.
cons:
Communication between different branches of the University can be lacking at times (e.g., communication between the Graduate College and students regarding deadlines)

Newark, DE is not a very exciting place to live. Price of rent is high and it can be difficult to find a place to live.

review_title: UD is a good place to work
pros: For a postdoc, research is high quality, access to all the necessary resources, salary is plenty to live on, 401k matching is unheard of, plenty to do in surrounding areas on holidays/weekends
cons: Parts of surrounding area are not necessarily safe, but that information is readily available and the areas can easily be avoided

review_title: It was a very fulfilling experience in that I got to work with each aspect of the job field I was working within.
pros: Great benefits and good leadership. Delaware is very up and coming! They are expanding in every department and hiring more qualified employees.
cons: Frustrating lines of communication and they are still putting their systems into place so some details are out of wack.

job_title: Research Associate I in Newark, DE
pros: The benefits are great at UD.  Annual merit raises are fair and properly reflect hard work and experience.  Employee perks are frequent and very popular (i.e. discount sports tickets, employee appreciation events, etc).  Since the University is closed during that time, having 7-10days off between Christmas and New Years is wonderful (without having to use any accumulated time)!
cons: The nature of my employment is grant funded.  Therefore, I do not have the opportunity to stay permanently.

pros: UD is unusual in that most masters students can get funding; this is what caused me to choose Delaware.  The workload for a grad assistant really depends on the specific faculty members you will be working for.  I was primarily grading papers, and worked far less than my officially alotted 10 hours/week.
cons: Stipends are lower than at many other schools.

pros: University of Delaware has an amazing Mechanical  Engineering Program.  The teachers are great and so are the schools resources, especially the free ones.
cons: Living in Newark can be a pain.  It seems like they do not like the students, and they ticket like crazy. Not to mention 25 cents only gets you 12 minutes of parking time.

review_title: If your job is secure, it's good for the long term
pros: We've continued to get raises (even if only 2%) without furloughs. Development and reaching alumni has improved with this newer University President Patrick Harker. I feel secure in my position, even with coming changes. Good professional development opportunities.
cons: Responsibility-based budgeting --the kinks are still getting worked out --especially for central services.  Moral is at an all-time low because many of the senior leadership have left after leaving wide paths of destruction.

review_title: University of Delaware, beautiful place to work, but has it's problems
pros: Great benefits and community.  The university has a beautiful campus and a great atmosphere.  The full-time benefits package is fantastic, starting with a full month's worth of vacation days.
cons: When President Harker took over, he turned the school into a business.  A lot of people lost their jobs with no reason given and the staff who were left still feel insecure about their positions.

job_title: Student Computer Technician in Newark, DE
pros: Flexible schedule, when work was at a minimum a service technician was still needed so I basically got paid to be on call on the site and to clean. (I like cleaning and doing maintenance on work machines so it was great for me to get paid to clean the counters and such) When things got busy it was fun, like a non stop torrent of computers
cons: The scheduling was flexible but your hours had to be between 8-6 m-f

review_title: A very nice place to work at as a Post-doctoral researcher. Though a lot depends on the group you belong to.
pros: UD has good benefits, good facilities and good research going on. With the new Interdisciplinary Science and Engineering lab, the equipment facilities at UD would be at par with any company.
cons: The paper work takes a long time to process sometimes. (not always) So if your employment is going to be renewed, you should start processing that before hand,

review_title: very productive and helpful for professional growth
pros: it has healthy academic atmosphere. the cooperation among departments or different disciplines is very frequent. good diversity and very strong in some majors such as chemical engineering
cons: parking is definitely a problem after the university decides to do more construction. not enough parking space compared with the parking permits sold to people

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Newark, DE
pros: Some of the research facilities are new and comparable to top schools; strong research programs in Chemical Engineering, Physical Therapy etc.; good location for people in Statistics, Finance and Chemistry/Chemical Engineering
cons: a lot of tenured professors are not doing their jobs mentoring graduate students, or agile or brave to start new research areas; high school cost for graduate students even with stipend from research funding; a lot of miscellaneous fees plus expensive parking permit graduate students have to pay

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Newark, DE
pros:
Great benefits if you have children that attend UD
 Time off vacation/office closed
cons: Pay for parking around $700.00 per year, I only make $32000.00 per year and have been here 8 years. Our pay increase has been 2% last year and 1% for 4 years prior. When you add the increase in parking every year and increase in benefits= no increase in my pay.

pros: Great flexibility. The supervisiors really understand you and want you to succeed as a student. SO as long as you preform your duties at the job, they will be very understanding and flexiable in your needs as a student.
cons: getting a job as a student is a little tricky. but it's easier to get it if you have connections.

review_title: I am a Math graduate student at University of Delaware and mostly of my funding came from Teaching and Research.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Newark, DE
pros: The professors are nice and there is a diverse group of people working in Applied Mathematics problems.
cons: The math department mostly funded students with teaching assistant money, which is not good since that took a lot of their time on research.

review_title: Very good experience, I am a former graduate student.
pros: Community is very strong, many extracurricular opportunities, events, speakers. Close to PHL, Baltimore, New York and DC. Very positive experience working here.
cons: I really don't have any but the location may not be great for some if you are not from the East coast/not looking to move here. Some people are not pleased with the new President but I am not affected by the administration much.

review_title: Benefits aren't worth selling your soul
pros: Benefits are good, generous vacation and sick leave policy
cons:
Low pay, unethical professors and administrators.
Any increase in pay is eaten up by the increase in parking fees.

job_title: English Language Institute in Newark, DE
pros: Great pay and a great schedule. The other instructors are wonderful.
cons:
If you're a female, your work and efforts will never be recognized, let alone rewarded. Promotions, perks, opportunities, etc. are consistently given to underqualified, underperforming males. Wear a suit, gentlemen, and you can enjoy growing in your job without having to go the extra mile!

Christians-- Advertise it. Anyone else-- Keep your mouth shut and sing the Christmas songs at the holiday party.

review_title: Have acquired a broad set of skills as a graduate student.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Newark, DE
pros: Large amount of freedom and a diverse group of coworkers.  Sometimes you get to travel to conferences at the university’s expense.
cons: Everybody has a different experience.  Some people don’t end up completing their desired degree objective.  A lot of this has to do with advisor selection.  Be sure to meet with as many potential advisors as possible be signing up for research.

review_title: Tough but rewarding ChemE PhD program
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Newark, DE
pros: great community, collaborative work environment, recent improvements in industry focused events, name recognition (ChemE department), campus events with UDairy ice cream
cons: intense first-year course load, few opportunities for PhD level internships (advisor dependent)

pros: you get higher pay if you are from a famous university or you got a PHD degree which is a requirement if you want to be successful in the academic industry.
cons: very bureaucratic and old fashioned place to work,if you want with a group of old people and not innovative ones, it is

review_title: A really great place to start
pros:
- Helpful coworkers; genuinely pleasant work environment
- Hires employees from a variety of backgrounds (as opposed to just MBAs or general HR/Administrative Professionals), allowing for a greater variety of opinions and more creativity
- The university entrusts even junior staff members with a surprising amount of responsibility; great opportunities for growth and learning provided you work hard
cons: - No particularly bad job experiences to report

pros: Classes are informative and prepare you for relevant challenges. Great pay and love job. Great resources to help get work done and lab set up. Great safety culture.
cons: Difficult work and very long hours. Lots of late nights and sometimes weekends. Best thing about Newark is the worst thing, which is the locations. A little too much of a college town.

pros: Hours are worked out around your school schedule, research can be performed in an area of your interest if you find the right professor, and summer scholars is a completely valid option if you form a great relationships
cons: Sometimes early hours can wear on you if your major calls for late nights. Scheduling and group communcitation are very important

review_title: UD is a great place to work.
pros: UD has a beautiful campus and offers great benefits to postdocs (who are classified as staff), including a free staff gym, parking near campus buildings, tuition benefits, and employer contributions to retirement accounts.
cons: My only complaint is that I can't work here longer, since UD puts a 3 year limit on postdoc contracts. Also, Newark, DE is not a particularly exciting place to live!

review_title: Best four years of my life
pros: The social life and the hard academic work made this the perfect balance between work and play.  There are tons of opportunities at the university which need to be taken advantage of.
cons: It is what you make of it.  Nothing will be handed to you, you have to get engaged and involved on your own.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Newark, DE
pros: Really flexible hours, ability to work on some fantastic projects, good networking opportunities -- you get out of it what you put in.
cons: Graduate school can get really long and grinding, academia has a strange set of politics.  Graduate student "stipend" or "pay" is pretty low.  The program doesn't really tailor for real jobs, a lot of solo work whereas industry is dominated by teamwork.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Newark, DE
pros: Excellent academic environment. Friendly and nice people. Great classes both in graduate and undergraduate level. Excellent research environment and facilities. Great collaborative options.
cons: Too much of partying culture among the undergrads. Wish the graduate students had more benefits and had more opportunities for career and professional development. Some parts of the campus like parts of the south campus are neglected in terms of infrastructure.

review_title: I improved my computing skills, and knowledge
pros: It is a well known university. We do research, do analysis, publish papers. During the semester, we learn a lot from professors.
cons: The course work is dense. There are many homeworks to do. So it takes some time to complete  the homeworks.

review_title: Good experience, but a long way to go to become a first tier university.
pros: Good professors, good curriculum. Decent infrastructure.
cons:
Parking is unavailable. School should provide free dedicated parking to students.

Software such as MS Office should be provided for free to grad students.

Grad student office needs to be more flexible in their approach.

pros: University of Delaware has awesome benefits and health rewards, millions of places to apply in all areas of the university, college classes for free as employees, and flexibility.  The entire culture of the college is growth oriented and truly engaged.  Should a person decide to continue college, there are tremendous opportunities for hands on practice and learning.
cons: HR policies and time needed to process any paperwork.

job_title: Digital Collections Assistant in Newark, DE
pros: Got to make your own schedule - weren't strict about missing a couple of days or being late. Opportunity to study while working. No minimum number of hours - great for students.
cons: Absolutely boring work. Ineffective supervisor who was very difficult to understand.

review_title: I had a great experience working at University of Delaware
pros: The department I work in has state-of-the-art instruments. Co-workers are friendly and willing to help you, share resources and or collaborate.
cons: Unfortunately, as a postdoctoral researcher and university employee, I am not informed about activities that can enrich my knowledge or help my research, such as invited faculty seminars, thesis defenses or symposia taking place in our department.

review_title: Good place for an academic without extremely high ambitions
pros:
- Good benefits 
- Collegial and smart colleagues
- Reasonably good students
cons:
UD has some problems funding repairs and new buildings it needs (especially in CAS). A lot of money sunk into the south campus that doesn't benefit students and faculty who are not in health sciences. Could have been used to build on core strengths.
Leadership can be mercurial, opaque.

pros:
student to faculty ratio is good... quality research faculty..
oppurtunuties given to travel to conferences and interact with other researchers is good
cons:
small department so the range of research areas is small
limited course work no exciting courses for graduate studen

review_title: Supportive research university, allows you to work at your desired pace
pros:
- Work at your desired pace, make your own hours as long as you're getting the job done
- Supportive research facility
- Excellent access to others research via seminars, presentations, email notifications
- Pay for graduate students is average
cons:
- Pay for graduate students is average
- Research at your own pace means your advisors may keep unusual hours

review_title: Beneficial work experience with fair pay.
pros: aesthetically pleasing work environment with many departments to branch out into. Older staff members have no problem going out of their way to assist you in an area you are struggling.
cons: This university is very bureaucratic and in a lot of areas has a lot of red tape and "hoops" to jump through in order to get permission to do certain things.

review_title: University of Delaware has Become a School to Recon with...
pros: The university has come a long way in the 30 years I have been here. Acceptance GPA's are higher than ever and it is finally becoming more diversified.
cons: The RBB initiative (responsibility based budgeting) makes retaining enough staff, to support faculty and research needs, more difficult. Employees are definitely doing "more with less".

pros: Nice city, close to nearby big cities like NY, DC. Decent pay for the job. Living cost is low.
cons: not many industries around. Might be difficult to job hunting after graduation. But that's also case by case. Depends on your work experience and network.

pros: Amazing and supportive work environment. The people with whom I had the pleasure of working felt like family to me. I couldn't have asked for a better professional experience while attending classes.
cons: The Hen Zone was renovated after I graduated and left Delaware, and I wish they had done so sooner, because I spent long periods of time in that desolate dungeon.

pros: Good graduate school program. Good geographic location.
cons: University's size is relatively small. Ranking is not high among colleges. However, campus is too crowded. Student activity fee and student health fee increase every year more than the salary increase.

pros: UD is a very generous employer. The benefits are incredible. Lots of really nice people.
cons: Slow-moving in decision-making. Decentralized structure makes communications and marketing additionally challenging.

review_title: A good place to learn new stuffs
pros: I am pursuing a PhD during the last five years and research assistant is a part-time job. The payment is okay for student and the experience here highly depend on your supervisor.
cons: Most of the time the work is intense and you need to spend some extra time if you want to finish your project before due.

pros: I have worked for a few institutions of higher learning, and my experience at UD was by far the best. I have worked in several departments, but my best experience was probably at The Alfred Lerner Graduate School of Business. I highly recommend this campus to anyone looking for an inspiring educational employer.
cons: none that I can remember

review_title: Postdoctoral researcher at University of Delaware
pros: You can enjoy living next to the great cities nearby, Philadelphia, Whashington DC, New York and Baltimore.
cons: You need to reach out farther to get connected and it gets even harder to get a real job unless you consider a relocation a must.

pros: Short distance to PHL, DC and NYC allows you easily shop and hang out in a big city. Main street located in Newark campus is ranked at top 10.
cons: Students do not have a lot of homework and professors are not push enough..l. so student need to be self motivated.

pros: This is a good lab to work . Freedom is given to look into the literature and defining a project
cons: Little difficult to manage research and courses together. No good co-ordination among the members to exchange knowledge. Should give more facilities

review_title: Wonderful Place to Work - with GREAT Benefits
pros:
Retirement - Employee contributes 5 % to get 11% Employer Contribution
Best Health Care Plan with almost no deductible payments
Vacation - 22 days per Calendar Year
Sick Leave - 18 days per year
Christmas to New Year paid Holiday Break
cons:
- Standard Increase to accommodate Cost of living  increase (2% to 3%)
-No Bonus Pay

pros: They are very willing to work around my class schedule and I never have to work weekends, which is nice.
cons: There aren't really many opportunities for advancement unless you have at least a master's degree.  It's definitely not a place I can see myself working at long term.

review_title: Sometimes a great lace to work, sometimes they can be completely evil.
pros: Flexibility and benefits.  It's not a bank, and you get to have a life at home.
cons: Staff aren't really valued, they barely notice that we exist.  It's all about the faculty and students.

review_title: University of Delaware Admissions Office Tour Guide
job_title: Blue Hen Ambassador in Newark, DE
pros: very friendly work environment, very social outside of the office, administration responsive to needs of employees, very flexible schedule, good opportunities for advancement
cons: low compensation, location itself not great (though 45 mins to philly and 3 hours to NYC or DC), requires work outdoors in inclement weather

review_title: It is certainly not one of the best, but it is okay
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Newark, DE
pros: The location is not bad. Close to Philadelphia, NYC and Washington D.C. Great for gob hunting if you are in financial area.
cons: One of top party schools. Academic atmosphere is definitely not as good as some other top universities. Research funding is usually limited

review_title: Restrictive, but a good part time job.
pros: The hours are extremely flexible, as you are only required a certain amount per week, but can fulfill those hours any night.
cons: The restrictive rules for conduct at one's station make it difficult for a student to read or catch up on work while waiting for calls to go through.

pros: It was a fun job getting to meet people from all over the world. Unfortunately, it was like trying to get people to be your friends that don't want to be.
cons: The leadership of ELI is predominately made up of very conservative Christians that encourage foreign students to convert to their religion.

pros: Lots of options for work study and jobs are typically very easy and flexible around student schedules.
cons: Almost all student jobs are minimum wage which is not enough to support a college student.

review_title: Professor at the University of Delaware, Newark
pros:
Great colleagues

Beautiful campus

Easy access to Philly, Baltimore, Washington, DC by train
cons:
Limited public transport onto campus -- or at least not easy to give up use of car if you live at any distance

Hierarchical leadership structure --not faculty/student/staff centric in some important ways

Known to be a party school

review_title: Excellent opportunities for students, fewer for graduates...
job_title: Senior Multimedia Assistant in Newark, DE
pros: Great management, positive work environment, friendly colleagues. Excellent communication among Library and Design Center staff. Strong emphasis on customer service is evident and welcome.
cons: As a student, I have had plenty of opportunities for part time and piecemeal jobs, but the opportunities number far fewer immediately upon graduation.

pros: Wonderful work environment, excellent benefits packages, tuition reimbursement, tuition remission (if you have dependents), flex hours in some positions
cons: Compensation for non-exempt employees is lagging behind industry standards, no clear-cut path for advancement, parking in Newark DE is pretty horrible.
